clinical_study.brief_title: S-1 and Radiotherapy for Elderly Esophageal Cancer Patients
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase Ⅱ Study of S-1 With Concurrent Radiotherapy in Elderly Esophageal Cancer Patients

brief_summary.textblock: To investigate the efficacy and toxicity of S-1 with concurrent radiotherapy in older patients with esophageal cancer.

detailed_description.textblock: Older patients with esophageal cancer have been correlated with poor prognosis because of having little chance to receive aggressive local therapy, including concurrent chemoradiotherapy. In this phase II trial, the efficacy and toxicity of S-1 with concurrent radiotherapy will be investigated in this setting.

primary_outcome.description: Response rate will be done after 3-4 weeks following the last radiotherapy session.

secondary_outcome.description: Progression-free survival (PFS) will be calculated from the date of CCRT initiation to the date of documented failure (local recurrence or metastasis occurrence) or the date of the last follow-up for those remaining.

secondary_outcome.measure: Acute and late toxicities assessed based on the common toxicity criteria for adverse events version 3.0 (CTCAEv3.0)
secondary_outcome.description: Acute and late toxicities will be assessed based on the common toxicity criteria for adverse events version 3.0 (CTCAEv3.0).
Overall survival (OS) wiil be determined as the time (in months) between the first day of therapy and the last follow-up or the date of death.

arm_group.description: Radiotherapy will be delivered with a daily fraction of 1.8-2.0Gy to a total dose of 54-60Gy. Preplanned concurrent S-1 (70mg/m²/day) will be administered on Day 1 for 14 days, every 3 weeks. After CCRT, maintenance S-1 will be given up to four cycles.

intervention.description: S-1 will be administered orally twice daily for 14 days at a dose of 70 mg/m2/day with concurrent radiotherapy for 2 cycles. Patients who showed a response greater than that of stable disease underwent additional S-1 until disease progression, serious adverse events, or patient refusal up to six cycles.
Radiotherapy wiil be delivered with a daily fraction of 1.8-2.0Gy to a total dose of 54-60Gy.
